[h1] Abiotic Factor – Science, Survival, and Shenanigans Underground [/h1]

Abiotic Factor drops you into the sprawling underground labs of GATE, a research company packed with “the world’s greatest minds.” On your very first day, a containment breach unleashes creatures from other dimensions, trapping you and up to five fellow scientists deep below the surface. Now, survival means crafting, scavenging, and occasionally smacking monsters with office furniture.

Part Half-Life, part survival sandbox, the game mixes humor, horror, and creative crafting into a surprisingly deep experience. You start with basic tools and scraps, but soon you’re inventing weapons, building base camps out of cubicle walls, and even decorating your safe zone with fridges and arcade machines. The ability to flatpack and move furniture is a particularly clever touch.

While Abiotic Factor can be played solo, it truly shines in co-op, letting you and your friends survive the madness together. You’ll manage hunger, thirst, and even bathroom breaks (yes, really), all while exploring a maze-like facility full of clever level design, looping shortcuts, and dangerous secrets. Each area feels distinct, and venturing deeper introduces stranger worlds beyond our own.

Combat can be clunky early on, and the crafting menus occasionally awkward, but the charm and depth of its systems make up for it. The writing is witty, the setting is full of discovery, and there’s a real sense of progression as you unlock new perks, gadgets, and areas.

After 10 hours, it’s clear there’s still so much left to uncover. Abiotic Factor is one of those rare survival games that balances depth, creativity, and personality, rewarding both careful thinkers and chaotic experimenters.

[h2]The air feels different...[/h2]

In Half-Life you played as Gordon Freeman. In Opposing Force you played as Adrian Shephard. In Blue Shift you played as Barney Calhoun. In Abiotic Factor you play as Isaac Klei... nah.. this game is a thing of its own. Though sometimes it does feel like playing Half-Life more than Half-Life itself.

So what is Abiotic Factor? It's a highly immersive survival crafting game heavily inspired by Half-Life (with some Half-Life 2 sprinkled in). Your aim in this game is to explore, survive and escape an abandoned science facility. The survival aspect is pretty strong in this one; you not only have to manage your hunger, thirst and toilet needs, but also consider radiation, heat and cold, sickness, bleeding, etc. Oh yeah, you can also easily break your bones if you jump from a high enough distance which would otherwise feel "not that high" (thanks to other video games spoiling us). All of this sounds overwhelming, right? Well, surprisingly, it's not. Sometimes it's relaxing even, because there is no time limit and you can focus on building and beautifying your base instead of advancing the story. The overall game difficulty is knowledge-based, which means challenging if you go in blind (I highly recommend doing so), but becomes pretty manageable/easy once you figure it out. The lore and story bits are also top notch.

I know Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 will sweep the awards this year (rightfully so), but I definitely think Abiotic Factor deserves an award one way or another. I had great fun playing it and looking forward to playing more DLCs and sequels for it. So I highly recomme...

tl;dr: It is a very long and sometimes tedious Half-Life 1 with crafting-survival.

What if Half-Life wasn't linear and instead each segments of black mesa were inter-connected? What if you didn't have the almighty HEV suit? What if overcoming hurdles didn't mean solving valve puzzles or blasting through? What if Half-Life was beatable no less than 90 hours? This game answers all of those questions with "yes", for better or worse.

Game has a story and you explore more and more of a facility, but it can be frustrating when you just want to get to the next section, so I don't recommend binging it and trying to "casual speedrun" it though, still, gathering some resources just to get to the next section can be very annoying and taxing on your mental health.

It's quite innovative to have craft-survival game set in a pre-made enclosed space (as opposed to procgen open-world) and somehow concept works, most of the time. It doesn't quite work when you need to collect some rarer resources since they only respawn in "parallel universes" or "Anteverses" as game calls them.

Some of the game mechanics and very specific things are non-intuitive so prepare to visit the wiki or do your own "research" on item descriptions, maybe you're smarter than me and you'll figure some things out on your own.

I wish my friends were playing this game (with me).

Story and the world takes a lot of inspiration from multiple universes, like (once again) half-life, SCP, maybe a bit of stargate sprinkle even? 

(minor spoilers below) 
The premise itself claims that 
[spoiler] you work as a newcomers in a non-governmental secret science facility, which learned how to open portals to different dimensions. That allows us to make scientific wonders and advances humanity's technology level at light speed. The most unusual objects are taken from such worlds and are kept inside the facility under a huge reliable lock. Think of your SCP objects held in cameras, w. description, safety precautions, measures to sustain & control them. 

However once the portal to another dimension opened, that connection cannot be fully closed and, what's worse, it impacts our planet too. E.g. Destruction of a distant universe might collapse our world as well. Or an (un)friendly visitor might want to check what's happening on our side of the portal, for example. 

Needless to say that we're playing with fire, so when 'The Order', (a secret society of humanity protectors. Or at least that's what they call themselves) finds out about our discoveries, they immediately send the execution crew to purge everything with fire, killing all the witnesses, stopping the experiments and destroying the facility.

But something goes seriously wrong and instead of making a swift n easy win, The Order causes actual resonance cascade, a bit similar to half-life. The facility locks down, so nobody can come in, or out. 

Now our task is to survive and escape the facility. For that we'll have to restore facility's functionality by gathering the necessary materials via travelling to the other dimensions. 

Each of such worlds takes inspirations from different games by the way. Resident evil, silent hill / the mist, dark souls, black mesa's xen, to name a few.[/spoiler] 
(end of the premise part) 

Then again, it's not like majority of players are going to follow the storyline when they are messing with friends. And trust me, the game gives you lots of ways to troll the folks.

Anyways, yes. Me like. Me recommend. Buy it! Good gaem!

Why is Abiotic Factor good?  It's a Half-Life and SCP mash-up in co-op with some New Zealand sprinkles on top.  Everything about this game is good, how about that?  I bought in during early access and I DON'T regret it.  Amazing.  10/10.  Thank you, islanders.

For a more technical review, the game is a co-op survival enterprise that takes place in a secret research facility that is deep underground called GATE.  The game begins when you enter this vast complex.  When you start your own server there are many sandbox settings you can play with to tweak the difficulty and because the devs are cool, they give guidance on which settings will alter the experience from what they intended for the game originally.  Up to 6 players can join a vanilla server.  You start with nothing beyond picking a character class which might give you some passive buffs (and debuffs--to a very detailed extent) and the first character you interact with is a salty scientist who just wanted to get a coffee in the cafeteria and "Now all hell has broken loose", which is an understatement.  There is a lot of dark humor throughout the game as the story progresses and the progression is seamless in the sense that you need to upgrade your keycard access (an in-game item) to actually get access to deeper levels in GATE.  As you go deeper, the enemies become tougher and you learn more of the dense lore and it's a very natural feeling which is more than I can say for a lot of slop games with arbitrary difficulty curves.  I also appreciate the fact that there is a storyline to follow from beginning to end but the game doesn't force you to progress if you don't want to.  Hell, if you want to, you can just kick back and fish for hours.

Quickly, it is a survival game so there is hunger, thirst, radiation (and other environmental hazards), a rest/sleep mechanic and most everything you own you have to make yourself at some kind of crafting table.  The visual style is a "low poly" type on par with say, Valheim, (which I also love) in fact you could say these two games are two sides of a coin--one fantasy/mythology themed and the other science-fiction themed.  I want to stress that fans of SCP lore will love Abiotic Factor for all of it's discoverable lore (there is a massive in-game journal devoted to this).  Deep Field (devs) do regular surveys of their players and continue to add content to what is obviously a passion project for them.  There is nothing to stop them from adding a new level to GATE on a regular or semi-regular basis as I know that I will eat that stuff up and I'm sure I am not alone in this.

To conclude and be concise: you should buy this game with money.  I am skipping story discussion because all you need to know is a calamity occurs in GATE and now you have to survive it.  Off you go then!  Mondays, AMIRITE?

This is an exceptional survival game that draws heavy inspiration from Half-Life. It is, without a shadow of a doubt, one of the most engrossing and charming games that I have ever played. The environments are beautifully crafted, and exploring them and learning more about this world is an absolute wonder.

Abiotic Factor is a funny and extremely creative sandbox experience, with a special focus on exploration and crafting, that gives you a multitude of ways to play. If you want to just get weapons and power through each zone, you can do that. If you want to spend countless hours, meticulously designing and decorating your base and building up defences, you can do that. If you want to be a nomad and keep moving around the map, you can absolutely do that as well. 

There are tons of decorative pieces and craftable items for you to find, so if that’s your sort of thing, you’ll probably have a blast here. The game is quite ingenious in the way that pretty much everything that you can craft has this really unique DIY look to it. Things absolutely look like what some scientists would pull out in the event of finding themselves stranded and unsupervised, and I absolutely love it.

The combat felt clunky at first, but once I got the hang of it, it’s decent enough that it didn’t get in the way of my enjoyment. There’s a decent variety of weapons at your disposal, and, as you progress through each zone, the game keeps introducing new tools, which keep the game interesting and fun.

What surprised me the most about the game was how the whole map is laid out. The game takes place in an underground research facility, and there are various areas of said facility that you’ll be able to explore, but what is so fascinating is how well they are interconnected. The layout makes sense, and the shortcuts are game-changing. A door that you might find early in the game might give you a direct way to access an area of the map that you’ll only be able to access much later down the road.

With all that being said, I must admit that, even though the ending leaves things open for future content, or even a sequel, it still left a bit of a sour taste in my mouth. To put it bluntly, it felt rushed, but the journey was absolutely worth it.

Abiotic Factor is an absolute blast, and I’m sure that if you’re a fan of survival games, you’ll have a wonderful time here. If you’re also a fan of Half-Life, then I wholeheartedly recommend it.

Abiotic Factor is endlessly replayable despite its 'linear' story, and is packed full of charm, soul, and fun. It's a fresh take on the tired, old survival genre. It mixes multiple media inspirations into a quirky, science-y crafting survival game. And it does so in a fresh, innovative way that makes me grin ear to ear when I'm playing it. It's one of those games where I can tell the devs really do love and care about their game and community and I'm so glad that such a dev team, game, and community exists in this day and age.

I cannot recommend this game enough to anyone who likes survival games. The survival elements are done well and are highly customizable, so you can have as much or as little struggle as you desire (although more granularity wouldn't hurt!). If you're a fan of the SCP universe, there's something here for you. If you liked Half-Life or Half-Life 2, there's something here for you as well.

If you like cool sci-fi stories, there's definitely something here for you. You'll probably end up waiting an hour or two between each major story beat (which are given to you through recordings of various science team members), but the downtime between each story beat is full of interesting survival and crafting gameplay, so it's not a problem at all and actually subtly enhances the effect of each shred of story you're told.

When you first play Abiotic Factor, you have no idea what is going on. Alarms are blaring, lockdowns are in place, and a only a small handful of people are present inside the facility in which this game takes place. What happened? Who did it? Can we fix it? Can it be stopped? Am I in danger? You don't know - neither you, the player, nor your character. The game intelligently nudges you to be scientific about your approach to the game. Experiment, explore, and come up with your own ways to solve the various problems you'll run into. There's a shocking number of ways to solve a single problem. Therein lies the beauty of Abiotic Factor. It's your game, play it the way you want to, but remember who you are!

Anyway, I could go on and on about this game, but I've already written a small book on it. If you've made it this far, thank you for reading! Now, if you don't mind, I have more science to do...

Honestly, that alone sold me the SCP games we’ve gotten so far have been mid at best, but this one takes those concepts and does wonders with them. You can use SCP-like entities in your base, they attack you, you explore other dimensions there’s a ton of variety.

Absolutely stunning game, loved every moment of it. The design of the world, both thematically and mechanically, works incredibly well, and I've never played a game that felt like it respected my time this much. 

You'll never have those survival-game moments of having to walk for an hour just to reach the place you need to be to actually progress; the facility uses vertical space and a looping design to make sure that you're opening new shortcuts as you're progressing through the sectors. 

You'll (almost) never have those moments where you lose everything and need to farm for six hours just to get back to where you were. If you die, you drop your stuff, but not the stuff you're wearing or that is on your hotbar (i.e. most of the stuff you're actually using). 

Each sector is interesting, enemy entities require particular solutions, and the base sieges make base building entertaining rather than a simple progress gate. 

My one critique is that sometimes certain item recipes were locked behind crafting or looting a particular item that could be part of the game that you were not personally engaging with (for example, fishing).

What if you played Half Life from the perspective of a scientist trying to survive and figure things out after the resonance cascade? Also instead of aliens everything is very SCP themed? That's Abiotic Factor.

You're coming into work to do science and stuff but everything has gone off the rails. So you're coming into work, as are a bunch of friends, and you're all trying to survive, craft, and get to the bottom of the mysteries.

On one hand, if you're going in solo, it loses a lot. But with a group of 3-6, it really shines. Each player can pick a couple of things to specialize in and there's plenty of story to keep you going for a while. 

It's a little janky, but charming.

Game is totally worth the price of admission. Plenty of story for lore masters, gameplay is engaging yet not unfair which makes it a very good time, be it solo or with friends.

Graphics-wise, it runs under Unreal Engine 5 so I have seen more performance hitches than not due to Lumen-oriented global illumination, but without it the game looks a little too flat. With it? Oh boy.
Graphics give that vibe of Half-Life games without being outright rip-offs, which really sell the environment of it being a Black-Mesa-like facility that would house SCPs.

Gameplay-wise, there is a lot of stuff to do, starting with base-building - which becomes a large key factor for survival, leveling and preparation for combat/exploration of the facility. Build-wise, I sort of missed the consistency with the snap-grid system that the cubicle walls have, but that was easily solved with mods. Plenty of facilities to build however, and further on the base develops an almost TD-like genre if you're not willing on defending your base on your own.

Combat is quite tight, good amount of weaponry that'll give you options start-to-finish. Initially I expected to not see enough firearms for a full ranged build but I was not dissapointed after beating this game. Melee is an option too for the bonk builds.

Progression is quite satisfying - altbeit a little backtrack-ey at times, - but it gives one just enough to keep one hooked to keep playing - it sure did keep me playing!

The game also supports cross-play with stationoids and game pass users, so you can co-op this with your friends - regardless of the platform!

Now, this wouldn't be a review if there weren't a few criticisms. First and foremost, the aforementioned UE5 engine and Lumen lightning system usage. Nothing wrong with it, but it taxes one's PC quite heavily to deliver that global illumination, which kinda gatekeeps a lot of players out(though with some tuning, even Steam Deck players can run it).
Additionally, combat early on is a little bit of a glass cannon run until you get a hold of more armor/weapon options, especially in one particular sector that had me die repeatedly. But, if you keep your wits about, you should be fine.
Finally, base-building could benefit from having unified snap-grid system, as opposed to just leaving it to cubicle walls. But like I said - a drop-in mod solved that right away.

Overall, a very good game and I'm happy to see it's a candidate for the Golden Joystick awards for GOTY and best Indie of the year! Thank you and congratulations to the folks at Deep Field for making it so far with this game!

negative.review:
If you like first person exploration crafting style games then this might be one for you.

Unfortunately, it seriously misses the mark with my crew and I.  I'm now 29 hours in and not feeling any desire to return.

Abiotic Factor has a fun visual style, great humor, and a fun premise which gave all of us Half-Life 1 vibes, but it started out quite rough and only got worse from there.

The base game is so frustrating that we had to adjust many of the settings as far as item degradation and stack amounts, enemy health and respawning, friendly fire, how quickly hunger/thirst/bathroom needs/fatigue drain, the whole works.

It is a game of constantly micro-managing everything, of endlessly running around being lost looking for more supplies which you can't carry back with you because of limited inventory space.  Everything needs maintaining.  Weapons feel like they tickle enemies while they have no trouble hitting you, and good luck trying to hit them back.  Some of the melee weapons feel painlessly slow, not in animations but clicking repeatedly and having nothing happen (lightning spear.)  Projectile weapons lack any feeling or feedback and are extremely difficult to aim.

Trying to figure out where to go is another nightmare because the map is useless and the objectives, not to mention how you affect the world, are often not clearly presented.  We constantly have to switch over to various wikis and videos to figure out what we're missing, or how to turn off weather anomalies while we keep getting irradiated, or any number of steps which constantly breaks immersion and adds to our frustration.  I wound up spending a large amount of my time boiling water and cooking soups because I felt so lost.

The game is built solid.  It runs smooth and never crashed on us.  It's gotten overwhelmingly positive reviews so people are obviously enjoying it.  But for the three of us this game is its own level of hell.  I can't personally recommend it, but if it seems interesting then I would encourage reading more reviews and watching some gameplay videos so you can get a better understanding of it.  Just be prepared for a lot of busy work.

After playing through this game mostly twice, I don't recommend it unless you are a fan of survival crafting games. I thought the Half Life / SCP skin would carry a game design that was more favorable to action as opposed to survival crafting ... and maybe it did, but not enough. The game seriously dragged on and by around halfway through I was just tired of having to go get stuff to craft stuff to make progression items *after* reaching the progression point. Plus traversal isn't particularly fast, even with jetpack. My advice though is never make the jetpack, stick with the long jump pack. 

Is the game *good* ? Yes, it has compelling level design and a lot of content. But it's a time sink that I don't think is worthwhile. You'd probably get more mileage out of a JRPG.

I really wish this was just a simple first person shooter, and not a survival crafting game.

I didn't like how unrealistic the food and sleep requirements are. If you don't sleep or eat within a few hours of game time, the character dies. 

This may be common to the genre but it ruins it for me almost immediately. 

The food/sleep requirements change this "survival" game into a roguelike or puzzle game. I honestly don't know how people enjoy it. It's so tedious.
